summary:
I have graduated from TU Delft in aerospace engineering Control and Simulation track. I have research experience in reinforcement learning applied to aircraft control, specifically on applying an actor-critic variant reinforcement learning framework for online control of a high fidelity Cessna Citation II model.

I have worked at Netherlands Aerospace Centre (NLR) Aerospace Equipment and Qualification (ASEQ) department as an intern acquiring hands on engineering experience developing a prototype flight data collector with commercially available off-the-shelf (COTS) GPS receiver, IMU, and single board computer.

I am scheduled to start as CSE engineer at ASML Veldhoven on January 4th.

projects.title: Master Thesis on Reinforcement Learning Aircraft Controller Development
projects.description:
Goal:
- Contribute to the ongoing research within Guidance, Navigation and Control (GNC) group of implementing an adaptive reinforcement learning controller for the Cessna Citation II PH-LAB aircraft

Tasks completed:
- Literature survey to establish knowledge foundation on aircraft control and reinforcement learning
- Preliminary analysis of implementing Incremental Dual Heuristic Programming (IDHP) controller on a simplified Cessna Citation model in Matlab/Simulink
- Implemented both baseline and cascaded IDHP controller for high fidelity Cessna Citation model simulation
- Introduced realistic measurement noise and atmospheric gusts through simplified Dryden model
- Established IDHP aircraft altitude control
- Comparison analysis of baseline and cascaded IDHP controller structures
- IDHP controller performance analysis with measurement noise in varying gust scenario

Results:
- Extended IDHP aircraft rate control to altitude control with no prior training
- Demonstrated feasibility of cascaded IDHP aircraft controller structure
- Further closed the gap between simulation and reality by implementing measurement noise and atmospheric gusts

projects.title: Bachelor Thesis on Conceptual Design of a Sounding Rocket Capable of Reaching 100 km in Altitude
projects.description:
Background: 
After a successful launch of Stratos I in 2009 that reached an altitude of 12.3 km, DARE is developing a successor, STRATOS II, with a goal to reach 50 km altitude. In parallel, initial mission planning for the STRATOS III rocket with a goal to reach 120 km has been commissioned to a team of 10 bachelor students as part of a Design Synthesize Exercise (DSE) which form a collaborative bachelor thesis in the aerospace engineering faculty.

Goal:
- Using systems engineering, develop mission planning for the upcoming STRATOS III project

Tasks completed:
- Contribute to system level requirements generation as propulsion subsystem lead
- Generate propulsion subsystem requirements
- Contribute to resource budget generation
- Select oxidizer/fuel mixture utilizing a trade-off table
- Preliminary oxidizer tank sizing and design
- Select oxidizer temperature control method
- Simplified oxidizer temperature change simulation during cold oxygen injection based on energy balance equation in matlab
- Preliminary feed system design
- Preliminary solid grain composition determination

Results:
- Completed mission planning and conceptual design of STRATOS III rocket as a team 
- Conceptual/preliminary design of the propulsion subsystem

profile_positions.description:
Background:
As a participant of SMILE project with the goal of designing a launcher capable of carrying satellites up to 50 kg, NLR is seeking to maintain cost effectiveness by using Commercially available Off-The-Shelf (COTS) components for its roll attitude control system. As part of a feasibility study, NLR has commissioned a technology demonstrator prototype to be placed in the payload bay of the upcoming STRATOS III rocket developed by Delft Aerospace Rocket Engineering (DARE).

Goal:
- Develop a flight data collector payload which will be placed within the STRATOS III rocket capable of collecting, storing, and transmitting flight data from the provided Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) receiver and Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU)

Tasks completed:
- Communicated with DARE and NLR for formal requirements generation
- Familiarization with the provided IMU and GNSS receiver
- Single board computer selection
- Power delivery system design
- Support structure hardware design in AutoCAD
- Components acquisition
- Electrical interfacing
- Software development for data reception, storage, processing, transmission to STRATOS III onboard computer, and system status check in C on Linux operating system
- Internal functioning and external communication test

Result:
- Fully functioning flight data collector payload meeting STRATOS III payload bay requirements
profile_positions.title: Flight data collection payload prototype engineer
